questions.text: Read the following list of health indicators: Life expectancy at birth Infant mortality Literacy Rate Gross National Income PPP in US$ Life expectancy at age 1 Mean years of schooling Parameters that are included in the determination of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) are- Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

b, c, e The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) consolidates three indicators: Infant mortality Life expectancy at age one Literacy For each component, the performance of individual countries is placed on a scale of 0 to 100, where 0 represents an absolutely defined worst performance, and 100 represents an absolutely defined best performance. The composite index is calculated by averaging the three indicators, giving equal weight to each of them. The resulting PQLI is thus also scaled from 0 to 100.

questions.correct_answer: A. A and B are correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A and B are correct Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as “a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development: to lead a long and healthy life measured by life expectancy at birth; the ability to acquire knowledge, measured by mean years of schooling; and the ability to achieve a decent standard of living measured by gross national income per capita in PPP US$. HDI value ranges between 0 to 1. It is an objective component of the quality of life. The countries are divided into low HDI (< 0.550), medium HDI (0.550 to 0.699), high HDI (0.700-0.799), and very high HDI (>0.800). India comes in the medium human development category.

questions.text: Previously it was thought that only the agent is responsible for disease causation. Which of the following theory of disease causation is depicted here?

options.label: A
options.text: Concept of the germ theory of disease

options.label: C
options.text: Concept of web causation of disease

questions.correct_answer: A. Concept of the germ theory of disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Concept of the germ theory of disease The concept of cause embodied in the germ theory of disease is generally referred to as a one-to-one relationship between causal agent and disease. The disease model accordingly is: Disease agent → Man → Disease It is, however, now recognized that disease is rarely caused by a single agent alone but rather depends upon several factors which contribute to its occurrence. This was given by Louis Pasteur.

questions.text: The theory of the “Epidemiological web of causation” was forwarded by-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

McMahon & Pugh ‘Web of causation’ model of disease causation was suggested by McMahon & Pugh in their book: ‘Epidemiologic Principles & Methods.’ This model is ideally suited to the study of chronic disease , where the disease agent is often not known but is the outcome of interaction of multiple factors.

questions.correct_answer: C. Environment behaviour, culture, Physiological factors, ecological elements
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Environment behaviour, culture, Physiological factors, ecological elements The image here shows the advanced model of the triangle of epidemiology. This new model includes all facets of the communicable disease model to make it more relevant and useful with regard to today’s diseases, conditions, disorders, defects, injuries, and deaths. It also reflects the causes of current illnesses and conditions. The term ‘agent’ is replaced by causative factors. ‘Host’ is replaced by Groups or populations and their characteristics Behaviour, lifestyle factors, environmental causes, ecological elements, physical factors, and chronic diseases must also be considered.

questions.text: The epidemiology of myocardial infarction could be best explained by-

options.label: B
options.text: Advanced model of triangle of epidemiology

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Web causation of disease The model of web causation of disease was suggested by McMahon and Pugh. The “web of causation” considers all the predisposing factors of any type and their complex interrelationship with each other. The basic tenet of epidemiology is to study the clusters of causes and combination of effects and how they are related to each other. The web of causation model is ideally suited in the study of chronic diseases (eg. myocardial infarction) where the disease agent is often not known, but is the outcome of interaction of multiple factors
